para.sentence: If k is a fixed positive integer, then a number-theoretic function f isperiodic (mod k ) if f(n+k)=f(n), if n=1,2,\dots.
Examples are the Dirichlet characters (mod k ) and the greatest common divisor \left(n,k\right) regarded as a function of n.

Every function periodic (mod k ) can be expressed as a finite Fourier series of the form f(n)=\sum_{m=1}^{k}g(m)e^{2\pi\mathrm{i}mn/k}, where g(m) is also periodic (mod k ), and is given by g(m)=\dfrac{1}{k}\sum_{n=1}^{k}f(n)e^{-2\pi\mathrm{i}mn/k}.
An example is Ramanujan’s sum: c_{k}\left(n\right)=\sum_{m=1}^{k}\chi_{1}\left(m\right)e^{2\pi\mathrm{i}mn/k}, where \chi_{1} is the principal character (mod k ).
This is the sum of the n th powers of the primitive k th roots of unity.
It can also be expressed in terms of the Möbius function as a divisor sum: c_{k}\left(n\right)=\sum_{d\mathbin{|}\left(n,k\right)}d\mu\left(\frac{k}{d} \right).

More generally, if f and g are arbitrary, then the sum s_{k}(n)=\sum_{d\mathbin{|}\left(n,k\right)}f(d)g\left(\frac{k}{d}\right) is a periodic function of n\pmod{k} and has the finite Fourier-series expansion s_{k}(n)=\sum_{m=1}^{k}a_{k}(m)e^{2\pi\mathrm{i}mn/k}, where a_{k}(m)=\sum_{d\mathbin{|}\left(m,k\right)}g(d)f\left(\frac{k}{d}\right)\frac {d}{k}.
Another generalization of Ramanujan’s sum is the Gauss sum G\left(n,\chi\right) associated with a Dirichlet character \chi\pmod{k}.
It is defined by the relation G\left(n,\chi\right)=\sum_{m=1}^{k}\chi\left(m\right)e^{2\pi\mathrm{i}mn/k}.
G\left(n,\chi\right) is separable for some n if G\left(n,\chi\right)=\overline{\chi}(n)G\left(1,\chi\right).

For any Dirichlet character \chi\pmod{k} , G\left(n,\chi\right) is separable for n if \left(n,k\right)=1 , and is separable for every n if and only if G\left(n,\chi\right)=0 whenever \left(n,k\right)>1.
For a primitive character \chi\pmod{k} , G\left(n,\chi\right) is separable for every n , and |G\left(1,\chi\right)|^{2}=k.
Conversely, if G\left(n,\chi\right) is separable for every n , then \chi is primitive (mod k ).
The finite Fourier expansion of a primitive Dirichlet character \chi\pmod{k} has the form \chi\left(n\right)=\frac{G\left(1,\chi\right)}{k}\sum_{m=1}^{k}\overline{\chi} (m)e^{-2\pi\mathrm{i}mn/k}.
